ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was a great introduction to international legal fora and sovereignty from a legal perspective

I learned a lot about sovereignty and different forms of law that pertain to sovereignty and socioeconomic rights. We touched on multiple topics, such as space law, withholding aid, and cybersecurity. I learned how to think of rights and these forms of law in terms of states' obligations and sovereignty of the people.

Discussed the philosophical background of sovereignty, mechanisms of international law, and various schools of thought surrounding int. law, sovereignty, and socio-economic rights. We discussed "what is a right," how to protect rights and the implications of law & rights. Also, a lot of legal terms!
Becoming comfortable with expressing my ideas orally.

I developed a deeper understanding of international law and how it functions in the real world. I also learned about the legal contours of socio-economic rights and sovereignty, and the many factors that affect the achievement of socio-economic rights.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: great array of topic areas covered, well organized for student learning, good writing feedback
Weaknesses: none

I think the course was well led and the readings were interesting. The discussions were engaging and I feel that I learned a lot from the readings and the class discussions. The final paper was very open-ended so I got to explore a topic I was interested in that we hadn't gotten into. Naama was a great instructor and so eager to help. I think it was well paced and the assignments were reasonable.

Strengths: the material was quite interesting! The readings were engaging, if very dense (they were all primarily legal readings, so this is unsurprising). I especially enjoyed it when the discussions intersected w/ other social sciences. Naama was also just a lovely person who did seem to care a lot about her students and always tried to find ways of improving her teaching and the course itself. 
Weaknesses: discussions were sometimes tough to sustain. This was especially the case at the beginning of the semester, and although it improved, the class size of 9 made sustaining them painful at times. The assignments could have also been better explained, but this was less of an issue in the latter half of the course.

Strengths: the small size of the class makes you feel more comfortable and safe when speaking.

Weakness: sometimes there were too many readings to keep up.

I really appreciated that the readings were kept to a manageable length-- I was able to complete all of the readings before every class, which allowed me to be fully engaged in the discussions. Professor Omri was terrific at leading discussions; she encouraged us to think critically about everything that we read, and she was genuinely interested in our thoughts and ideas.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Naama is amazing and the class discussions were genuinely interesting every week
Yes! If anything on the syllabus or in the title interests you, I feel like there is something for you in this course. I found it so interesting and fun to be a part of.

I would, but only if they were interested in the subject and willing to put in the time to do the readings. This class is one of those courses that if you skim by, discussions, papers, and overall everything will be painful, and you'll get nothing out of it. Since it's a college seminar it probably won't be offered again though
Yes! Professor Omri is wonderful, and she made these complicated topics extremely approachable.
